Problem:
Consider a linear system described by the continuous Fourier transform \\( \\hat{f}(\\omega) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} f(t) e^{-i\\omega t} dt \\), where \\( f(t) \\) is a time-domain signal. We analyze the impact of a modulation defined by the function \\( g(t) = e^{i\\alpha t} \\) over time t, where \\( \\alpha \\) is a real constant.

If the modulation \\( g(t) \\) is applied to a signal \\( f(t) \\) resulting in \\( f'(t) = f(t)e^{i\\alpha t} \\), and then transformed by Fourier transform, will the frequency spectrum \\( \\hat{f}'(\\omega) \\) be the same as the unmodulated signal \\( \\hat{f}(\\omega) \\)?
Explanation: The modulation by \\( g(t) \\) shifts the frequency spectrum of the signal by \\( -\\alpha \\) units, as specified by the frequency shift property of the Fourier transform. Thus, the spectrum \\( \\hat{f}'(\\omega) \\) will be \\( \\hat{f}(\\omega - \\alpha) \\), different from the original \\( \\hat{f}(\\omega) \\).
